intro: Andeimalva peruviana, commonly known as the Peruvian mallow, is a herbaceous plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its soft, hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in the summer months. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Due to its ornamental value and traditional uses, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and for medicinal purposes.
